QuestionText: Suppose a baker incorrectly doubled the amount of sugar in the bread recipe. Besides making the bread sweeter, how this would affect the fermentation process and the final product?
Answers: Nothing will change in the final product other than being sweeter.
The bread will be toxic and inedible.
The bread will be flatter than the normal recipe.
The bread will be less dense than the normal recipe.

QuestionText: During the production of white wine, the skins of the grapes are removed. If you removed the skins before the first pressing instead of the before the second pressing, what would happen to the product?
Answers: The wine would be red instead of white.
Less wine would be obtained from the grapes.
No fermentation would take place.
The quality of the wine would be harder to control.

QuestionText: Imagine that a large wine distributor wanted to create a red wine that had a similar taste from year to year to sell all over the world. Which of these would be most important?
Answers: As long as wine makers used grapes grown in similar areas, the product would be consistent.
The winemakers would need to eliminate the natural yeasts and add specific strains of yeast.
The taste would be the same if the winemakers used the same temperature and storage conditions for each batch.
The winemakers would have to keep the skins on during the pressing of the grapes to get the same red pigment every time.

QuestionText: Some people dislike dryness that comes from the enzymes called tannins which are located in the skins and seeds of red grapes. Which of these techniques would be the most effective way to create a low tannin wine?
Answers: Let the must sit in the fermentation tank longer before removing the skins and seeds.
Remove the skins and seeds before pressing and add sugar to the pulp.
Heat the must after the first pressing and before removing the skins and seeds in a second pressing.
Remove the skins and seeds before pressing and add yeast to the pulp.

QuestionText: You are producing a home brewed beer. You measure the alcohol rate after fermenting, and it is at 11.5%. There is still residual sugar present in the beer. What will likely happen to the beer once it is in the bottle?
Answers: Nothing, once the beer is in the bottle, oxygen is removed which stops the fermentation process.
The residual sugar level will increase.
The alcohol level will increase.
The carbonation will decrease.

QuestionText: Which is true of anaerobic fermentation?
Answers: ATP is produced as pyruvate molecules are converted into carbon dioxide.
For sugars to be metabolized by yeast, oxygen must be present.
Sugars are converted to pyruvate molecules before they are converted into ethanol.
Oxygen is needed as a source of energy for the yeast.

QuestionText: Immediately prior to Pasteur’s discovery, what ingredients were brewers likely to put in their beer?
Answers: Water, Barley, Yeast
Water, Barley, Hops
Water, Hops, Yeast
Water, Hops, Sugar

QuestionText: What could be a reason for a wine to contain a large amount of residual sugars?
Answers: Yeast with a high attenuation rate were used.
All sugars have been metabolized by the yeast.
The wine has a very high alcohol content.
Toxicity causes the yeast to die before the glucose has been broken down.

QuestionText: When yeast cells have a low rather than high attenuation, what is more likely to happen to the beer or wine?
Answers: It will have a high alcohol content.
It will contain more residual sugars.
It will be preserved for a longer amount of time.
It will create a toxic environment.

QuestionText: Why is wine considered to be less complex to produce as compared to beer?
Answers: Wine does not require any additional ingredients to be added in addition to the sugar source.
Wine quality is easier to control.
Wine requires exact ratios of products to be added.
Wine requires a preservative.
A process where a sugar is broken down into ethanol alcohol and carbon dioxide.
A process where a sugar is broken down into yeast and carbon dioxide.
A process where yeast in broken down to ethanol alcohol and carbon dioxide.
A process where sugar is broken down to ethanol alcohol and yeast.

QuestionText: In the fermentation process, what molecule is immediately produced as yeast consume sugars?
Answers: Lactic Acid
Glucose
ATP
Carbon Dioxide

QuestionText: What is removed from the fermentation tank if the desired product is white wine?
Answers: Sugar and Stems
Yeast and Skins
Juice and Stems
Stems and Skins

QuestionText: What causes wine or beer to become toxic environment for yeast?
Answers: Increases in glucose
Decreases in oxygen
Decreases in pyruvate
Increases in alcohol

QuestionText: Crushing or breaking the skin of a grape is the first step in the fermentation process of wine. Why is this true?
Answers: The sugar is exposed to oxygen.
The sugar comes into contact with the yeast.
The sugar decreases carbon dioxide levels.
The sugar mixes with the pyruvate.
